did.unittitle: Ned Heindel collection relating to the establishment of American Chemical Society certification in Chemical Hygiene and Environmental Analytical Chemistry

bioghist.p: Ned D. Heindel (b. 1937) is Howard S. Bunn Professor of Chemistry at Lehigh University and is a Visiting Professor of Nuclear Medicine at Hahnemann University. He received his Ph.D. in organic chemistry from the University of Delaware in 1963. He was President of the American Chemical Society in 1994, and from 1985 to 1996 was a Director of the ACS. Between 1980 and 1987, Heindel was Director of Lehigh University's Center for Health Sciences. He has been a Trustee of the Chemical Heritage Foundation since 1986.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains, according to correspondence with the donor, "the paper trail of studies, endorsements, persuasions, and interactions which led -- in December 1995 -- to the ACS Board committing the funds to create two new certifications in Environmental Analytical Chemistry and in Chemical Hygiene. Panels of practitioners in both areas wrote, field-tested, and launched those certifications in 1996-1997. These programs are managed by NRCC [the National Registry in Clinical Chemistry, a multi-society sponsored management organization]." Records include correspondence, reports on certification guidelines, sample examination questions, and background reference materials. Also included in the collection are documents about discussions between the Society for Applied Spectroscopy and the Chemical Heritage Foundation about a spectroscopy museum.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
